name: Projects
body:
### **[HTML5 Netrek Client](https://github.com/apsillers/html5-netrek)**
**[[playable demo](https://netrek-apsillers.rhcloud.com/)]**

A browser-based client for the old-school space battle game [Netrek](http://www.netrek.org). Choose one of 5 different ship classes, and conquer the galaxy with superior dogfighting, strategy, and teamwork. Using HTML5 WebSockets, you can engage in real-time multiplayer combat, playing right alongside players using the full desktop client!

**Built with:** node.js, [CAKE.js](https://code.google.com/p/cakejs/) (canvas), [socket.io](http://socket.io) (networking)

***

### **[Taggem](https://github.com/apsillers/Taggem)**
**[[playable demo](https://taggem-apsillers.rhcloud.com/)]**

An experimental multiplayer real-time [roguelike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roguelike) you can play in your Web browser. The modular architecture of the code allows developers to quickly add new items and monsters to the game. In this simple demo implementation, you can battle nymphs, hide behind boulders, blast enemies with freezing wands, and use portal guns to teleport yourself around the dungeon.

**Built with:** node.js, [ROT.js](ondras.github.io/rot.js) (canvas/rougelike utilities), [socket.io](http://socket.io) (networking)

***

### **[Lords of the Fey](https://github.com/apsillers/lords-of-the-fey)**

A nascent re-implementation of [Battle for Wesnoth](http://www.wesnoth.org) for the Web using HTML5 technologies like WebSockets and the Canvas API.

**Built with:** node.js, [EaselJS](http://www.createjs.com/#!/EaselJS)/[PreloadJS](www.createjs.com/#!/PreloadJS) (canvas), [socket.io](http://socket.io) (networking), [Express](http://expressjs.com) (Web server and user auth)

***

### **[Stacklife](https://github.com/apsillers/stacklife)**
**[[demo](http://stackoverflow.com/users/710446/apsillers)]**

Simple static content creates an interactive implementation of [Conway's Game of Life](en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway's_Game_of_Life) that you can display virtually anywhere -- even in a Stack Overflow profile.

**Built with:** node.js, [Express](http://expressjs.com) (Web server)
